DOC.HEAD: New Order May Help Refugee Fleeing Forced Abortions
DOC.TEXT: A Chinese man jailed after he and his pregnant wife entered the United States illegally to flee a forced abortion in China hopes a presidential order will bring him freedom. Li Jin Lin's case is one of the first in the nation to test President Bush's directive that says fear of forced sterilization or abortion can be considered as grounds for granting an alien political asylum. The directive, though not specifically for Chinese, was part of Bush's Nov. 30 order allowing many Chinese citizens to remain in the United States indefinitely after the massacre of pro-democracy demonstrators in Beijing. Li, 37, and his wife, Wang Sai Zhen, fled their hometown of Fuzhou after she became pregnant with the couple's second child. Ms. Wang had been forced to have several abortions after the birth of her first daughter, now 10, because Chinese law limits most families to one child. She feared for her health if forced to undergo another, said Patrick W.H. Wesp, Li's lawyer. The daughter remains in China with relatives. The Lis entered the United States from Canada last March, but the U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service caught them in Albany and returned Li, 37, to Canada. Ms. Wang, whose age was unavailable, was allowed to remain because of her advanced pregnancy and gave birth to a girl in New York City. Li and his nephew, Chun Kong Cheung, tried once more to get into the United States, but border officers found them in the back of a tractor-trailer at the Peace Bridge on Oct. 14, Wesp said. The couple now fears harassment and worse if they should be returned to China, and their daughter could suffer even though she is a U.S. citizen by virtue of her birth here, said Kathleen Rimar, a lawyer representing them before the INS. ``Our research indicates that individuals who have had two children face sterilization in China,'' Rimar said. ``The child would never have any advantages in her life. She would be cut out of schooling, any chance at a job.'' She said Bush's directive ``doesn't grant people asylum but it gives them a better shot if they can prove they would be forced to abort or face sterilization.'' She added that it should apply even though the Lis were caught before the order was issued. John J. Ingham, acting district director of the INS, said the Lis are the first refugees in the Buffalo area to claim asylum because of their country's family-planning laws. Rimar and Wesp said that as far as they know, it is the first such case in the country. Li and his nephew are in jail awaiting trial on criminal charges of conspiracy to enter the United States illegally, Ingham said. He said the family should have requested political asylum at the border, but Rimar said the Lis neither speak English nor understand immigration law. ``They don't even know the word asylum,'' Rimar said.
